newsitem.title: GERMANY: Higher groundnut crops seen boosting 96/97 exports.
newsitem.headline: Higher groundnut crops seen boosting 96/97 exports.

text.p: Slightly higher global groundnut production and stocks drawdowns in the 1996/97 season should boost exports of edible peanuts, groundnut oil and meal, independent newsletter Oil World said on Tuesday.
Groundnut output was forecast at 19.62 million tonnes in 96/97 after 19.36 million tonnes in 95/96 and 96/97 crushings were put at 10.80 million after 10.41 million a year earlier.
Oil World said India's and Argentina's bigger crops would make up for shortfalls in the U.S., where the area was lower and large parts of the crop are still exposed to weather risks.
Senegal and South Africa were also seen raising output while China's was estimated six percent lower at 6.7 million.
Global exports of groundnuts in the 96/97 season were pegged at 1.34 million tonnes versus 1.32 million in 95/96.
Imports in the European Union (EU), which accounts for 43 percent of the world total, may rise to 574,000 tonnes (560,000 previously).
Groundnut oil and meal output were forecast to rise by four percent each to 4.35 million tonnes and 6.18 million tonnes.
Brazil and Argentina as well as African countries were likely to step up their oil exports, mainly to Europe.
In meal, higher exports should be absorbed by Asian feeds markets, mostly in Thailand and Indonesia, and the EU.
